articles.headline: Mugabe Foes Win Majority in Zimbabwe
articles.snippet: President Robert G. Mugabe’s ruling party lost control of the nation’s Parliament. Will the presidency be next?
articles.abstract: President Robert G. Mugabe’s ruling party lost control of the nation’s Parliament. Will the presidency be next?
articles.lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe  President Robert G. Mugabe and his party have lost control of the nation’s Parliament, official election returns showed Wednesday, giving new impetus to the bigger question: Does that foretell a loss of the presidency itself, the job he has held tightly for the past 28 years?

articles.headline: In Senate, Agreement on Housing
articles.snippet: Senate Democrats and Republicans reached a tentative deal on a package of tax breaks, grants and tax-exempt bonds to help homeowners and stabilize the housing market.
articles.abstract: Senate Democrats and Republicans reached a tentative deal on a package of tax breaks, grants and tax-exempt bonds to help homeowners and stabilize the housing market.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats and Republicans reached a tentative deal Wednesday on a package of legislation to help homeowners facing foreclosure, including new tax breaks intended to help stabilize the wider housing market.

articles.headline: At NBC, Supersizing the Season
articles.snippet: NBC’s promises include fewer reruns, 65 weeks of new shows, the return of favorites like “E.R.” and “Friday Night Lights,” and more product placements from sponsors.
articles.abstract: NBC’s promises include fewer reruns, 65 weeks of new shows, the return of favorites like “E.R.” and “Friday Night Lights,” and more product placements from sponsors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here are some of NBC’s big promises: fewer reruns, 65 weeks of new shows, the return of sentimental favorites like “E.R.” and “Friday Night Lights”  and more product placements from advertisers in its programs.

articles.headline: A Stormy Decade for Citi Since Travelers Merger
articles.snippet: The merger of Citicorp and Travelers, a deal that created a financial supermarket, is looking less visionary as the behemoth lumbers from one crisis to another.
articles.abstract: The merger of Citicorp and Travelers, a deal that created a financial supermarket, is looking less visionary as the behemoth lumbers from one crisis to another.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ten years ago this Sunday, on April 6, 1998, Sanford I. Weill rewrote the rules of Wall Street.

articles.headline: Fed Chief Sees Possible Contraction in First Half
articles.snippet: In citing the likelihood of a recession, Ben S. Bernanke said the home mortgage crisis remained the single biggest drag on prospects for a recovery.
articles.abstract: In citing the likelihood of a recession, Ben S. Bernanke said the home mortgage crisis remained the single biggest drag on prospects for a recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In his bleakest economic assessment to date, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said Wednesday that the American economy could contract in the first half of 2008, meeting the strict definition of a recession, and he called on Congress to strengthen the nation’s distressed housing industries.

articles.headline: Unsold Homes Tie Down Would-Be Transplants
articles.snippet: The housing crisis is distorting the job market, restricting workers’ ability to pursue better career opportunities.
articles.abstract: The housing crisis is distorting the job market, restricting workers’ ability to pursue better career opportunities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. Michele Morgan migrated last fall from Detroit to Phoenix, taking a job as a psychiatrist. She expected her husband, Sam Kirkland, to soon join her, since he was accepting an early retirement package from his employer, General Motors. But he cannot move, he says, because he has not been able to sell the four-bedroom family home.

articles.headline: A Camera for the Shot You Missed
articles.snippet: The FX-1 camera from Casio allows users to snap 60 shots a second, and that’s just the beginning.
articles.abstract: The FX-1 camera from Casio allows users to snap 60 shots a second, and that’s just the beginning.
articles.lead_paragraph: When you’re a professional gadget reviewer, you see plenty of cellphones, music players, camcorders and computers. But in two weeks, Casio will offer an entirely new device for sale, the first of its kind: a time machine.
